review_title: Starbucks is about as good as food service gets
pros: When everything shut down in March, Starbucks gave all of its employees a choice: to stay home and be paid an average weekly salary or to continue working with hazard pay. Not many other companies took care of their employees this well.
cons: Since things have opened back up, Starbucks has closed several stores and given its employees another choice: to continue working, minus hazard pay, at reduced hours or be involuntarily terminated in order to be available for other employment. And while they do offer health insurance after 20 hours a week, they try really hard to keep anyone not full time under 20 hours.

review_title: Fantastic place to work until you consider the opportunity cost
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Seattle, WA
pros:
Young and intelligent workforce comprised of people who genuinely like the company and the brand.  The focus on doing what is right for the customers is deeply ingrained within the corporate culture, as is doing what is best for employees.  
The work/life balance is great - the complete opposite of somewhere like Amazon
cons:
Although the organization is relatively flat, many decisions come from the very top.  The culture promotes gut over logic or facts as a basis for decision-making, which is a reflection of the poor data management systems within the company.  Hard data is hard to come by, and the company operates without great visibility around what is going on in the field.
The pay is terrible.  No buts about it.  At least once per day, I think to myself, "I'm happy with my job, but I'm really bitter about the compensation package."  
Also, the amount of vacation we receive is a joke.  For an experienced employee to come in and have only 2 weeks of vacation is ridiculous.

pros:
I worked for Starbucks for 4 years while going to school in the medical field. I worked in the same store and had three store managers in that time. 

The biggest pro for me was the flexibility. You want to take a weekend off to relax? That's fine. Maybe you want to take an entire week off to go on a vacation? That's fine too. Management doesn't pry, and you don't need to give them a reason. As long as you let them know ahead of time, they're cool about it. They'll also work around anyone's school schedule.

Another pro were the hours you get every week. When you start off, you'll only get a few hours since you have to learn everything. Once you learn how to do more, you'll start getting more hours. I was always scheduled at minimum 30 hours a week, but since people called out I usually worked at least 40. If you need more hours, you could always network with other partners, shifts, and managers to work at a different store that needs someone to fill in.

Speaking of starting off, Starbucks care about teaching their partners how to do their job. I've worked in fast-food places where they put you on the cash register and just tell you "figure it out." It was like throwing you to the wolves. Starbucks will assign a partner to stand next to you while you're learning to teach you and help you out in case you get stuck. They know it's hard learning so many new things at once, and want to see you succeed.

Lastly, you'll be given Starbucks stock. Every once in awhile, I forgot how often, you'll get more shares gifted to you. You can cash them out at any time and they're yours even after you quit.

Honestly, if I could make the same amount I make now in the medical field, I would go back to Starbucks. It's a great company, and I enjoyed my time there.
cons:
You'll sometimes get scheduled to close and then open the following morning. I've heard partners boast about sleeping in the parking lot in their cars so they wouldn't have to drive home and back. If you close and then open, you'll be lucky if you get four hours of sleep.

If you decide to become a shift, you're basically on-call 24/7. Don't become a shift if you want to keep your work and personal life separate.
